prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain Tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Mia Fey
Description: Maya's older sister and my eternal mentor in life and law. Passed away 2 years ago.
Character 2
Name: Godot
Description: A prosecutor who is shrouded in mystery. He seems to know me somehow.
Character 3
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 4
Name: Maggey Byrde
Description: A waitress at Trés Bien. Was found guilty of murder thanks to the phony me.
Character 5
Name: Jean Armstrong
Description: Trés Bien's owner and chef. A witness in the case who is also into aromatherapy.
Character 6
Name: Glen Elg
Description: The victim. Was a programmer. Maggey had apparently never even seen him before.
Character 7
Name: Victor Kudo
Description: Was in Trés Bien at the time of the incident. Has a thing for waitresses.
Character 8
Name: Lisa Basil
Description: The CEO of Blue Screens, Inc., and Glen Elg's boss. Absolutely not a robot.
Character 9
Name: Violetta → Viola Cadaverini
Description: Possibly part of the staff at Tender Lender? A thoroughly bitter person.
Character 10
Name: Furio Tigre
Description: The head of Tender Lender loan company. Also known as "The Tiger".
Character 11
Name: Bruto Cadaverini
Description: The head of the Cadaverini Family crime syndicate. Seems to live for his granddaughter.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: A present from Maya. It reacts to people who have secrets in their hearts. On loan from Maya. Recovered in the kitchen of Trés Bien.
Evidence 2
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An article from December 5th. Says I was trounced and my client was found guilty.
Evidence 3
Name: Sports Paper
Description: Dates from December 3rd, the day of the incident. On it is a doodle that said 'MC Bomber' with an arrow pointing to '100,000' that was crossed out. 'Ahahahaha' and a laughing face are written next to it. Left by a costumer in Trés Bien on Dec. 3rd. Click here for details. Left by the victim. Doodle is in victim's handwriting. Click here for details.
Evidence 4
Name: Job Listings
Description: Picked up from a bench in Vitamin Square. Thrown away by the old man.
Evidence 5
Name: Lunch Special
Description: Trés Bien lunch special. Costs 20 dollars despite how unbelievably bad it tastes.
Evidence 6
Name: Small Bottle
Description: Found in the kitchen. Shape is different from the others bottles. Contents unknown. The victim's ear medicine. Found covered in unidentified fingerprints in the kitchen. The victim's ear medicine. Covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints.
Evidence 7
Name: Scooter
Description: Ridden by my phony. The wheel guard is all smashed up.
Evidence 8
Name: Jean's Loan Contract
Description: Jean's debt is half a million dollars. The owner of the loan is Tender Lender.
Evidence 9
Name: Victor's Note
Description: "Convicted before, a wicked man or woman, repeat offender -- Victor Kudo"
Evidence 10
Name: Glen's Autopsy Report
Description: Died of potassium cyanide poisoning. Time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM.
Evidence 11
Name: Trés Bien Floor Plans
Description: Blueprints of the crime scene. Click here for details. X = victim's seat.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A photo of the scene taken from near the kitchen. Two dining tables are separated by a folding screen. The one closer to the camera is empty. The other one is where the victim collapse on the table. There is an intact vase on each table. A coffee cup is knocked over and the the table cloth is stained by coffee. Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
There was a prescription bag on the victim's table along with the lottery ticket.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a kind of scary old man, sir.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 1
Testimony: Poor Maggey had passed out from the shock. It must've been real tough for her.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The victim didn't have any identification on him.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 3
Testimony: But we figured out who he was pretty quick, and then the investigation went smoothly.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 4
Testimony: When Maggey was searched, we found the lottery ticket and the bottle of poison.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 5
Testimony: And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene.
Person: Gumshoe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me start by reading through all the information provided carefully.

First, I see that the testimonies are from Dick Gumshoe, the homicide detective. He's giving an account of the crime that happened at Trés Bien on December 3rd. According to Testimony 0, the crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a "kind of scary old man, sir." Gumshoe mentions that Maggey passed out from shock and that the victim, Glen Elg, didn't have any identification.

Looking at the evidence, Evidence 20 is Glen's Calendar, which shows a note saying "Meet with The Tiger" for December 3rd. This suggests that Glen had a meeting with Furio Tigre, who is the head of the loan company, Tender Lender. Additionally, Evidence 15 is the Victim's Prescription Bag, which was found empty.

Now, considering the testimonies, Gumshoe says that when they searched Maggey, they found the lottery ticket and the bottle of poison. However, there's no mention of any missing items from the crime scene, as per Testimony 5.

But wait, the calendar shows that Glen was supposed to meet with The Tiger. Furio Tigre is also mentioned in Evidence 25, which is a repair bill paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family. Furthermore, Evidence 24 mentions Trés Bien Matches found in Tender Lender, and Evidence 23 is the MC Bomber disc, a computer virus worth millions, also found there.

This makes me think that The Tiger (Furio Tigre) was involved in some capacity. If Glen was meeting with Tigre, maybe he was poisoned by someone, possibly Tigre or someone else connected to him. The fact that the prescription bag was empty and the calendar note exist seems to suggest that there was an intention to meet, but the crime happened at 2:25 PM, which is after the meeting time. This could imply that the poisoning occurred after the meeting or that the meeting itself was the setup for the crime.

However, the key point is that the crime scene didn't have anything missing, according to Testimony 5. But if the MC Bomber disc and matches were found in Tender Lender, it might suggest that the crime was part of a larger plot or that the items were planted there afterward, contradicting the testimony that nothing was missing.

Alternatively, the presence of the MC Bomber disc and matches in Tender Lender might not directly contradict the testimonies but rather add context about The Tiger's involvement. The calendar note aligns with the meeting, and the prescription bag being empty might indicate that Glen was there to pick up something, but without more evidence, it's hard to say.

Wait, maybe the key contradiction is that the crime was reported at 2:25 PM, but the meeting was supposed to happen at 1:30 PM. If the meeting didn't happen, why was the note there? Or perhaps the meeting did happen, and the crime occurred afterward, but the testimony says there was nothing missing from the scene, which might not directly contradict the other evidence.

Hmm, perhaps I'm overcomplicating this. The main points are the calendar note indicating a meeting, the items found in Tender Lender, and the testimonies about the crime scene. It seems like the evidence supports that The Tiger was involved, but the testimonies don't mention anything conflicting. Maybe the contradiction is that the crime scene had nothing missing, but the evidence shows that items were found elsewhere, implying a setup or after the fact.

Alternatively, the contradiction could be that the victim had a winning lottery ticket (Evidence 14), which was found during the body search of Maggey, suggesting that Maggey might have taken it, but the testimonies don't mention this, or perhaps it's a red herring.

I think the most straightforward contradiction is that the testimonies mention nothing was missing from the crime scene, but the evidence shows items like the MC Bomber disc and matches were found elsewhere, possibly after the crime, indicating something was taken or planted, which contradicts the testimony.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me start by going through the evidence and testimonies one by one to see if anything stands out as conflicting.

First, I'll look at the testimonies. Testimony 0 says that the young man was reading the sports paper. Testimony 1 mentions that the serving girl brought him a javaccino but put something in it. Testimony 2 says she put some white powder in it, which Testimony 3 confirms caused the man to collapse after one sip. Testimony 4 links the serving girl to the defendant's chair, and Testimony 5 describes her appearance with a ribbon in her hair and a loose apron.

Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 13 is the Coffee Cup, which contained potassium cyanide and had fingerprints from both the victim and Maggey. Evidence 6 is the Small Bottle, which was the victim's ear medicine but had Furio Tigre's fingerprints. Evidence 14 is the Victim's Lottery Ticket found on Maggey. Evidence 16 is the Potassium Cyanide found in Maggey's apron pocket. Evidence 17 is the Victim's Prescription Bag, which was empty.

Putting this together, the testimonies suggest that the serving girl (Maggey) was involved in the poisoning, as she added white powder to the coffee. However, the evidence shows that the potassium cyanide was found in Maggey's apron pocket, which aligns with her being the one who added the poison. The fingerprints on the coffee cup also support this, as both Maggey and the victim were present near it.

But wait, Testimony 6 says that there wasn't anything interesting about her appearance when seen from the front, which seems to contradict the description in Testimony 5 of her having a ribbon in her hair and a loose apron. This inconsistency suggests that the testimonies and evidence about her appearance might be conflicting.

However, looking back, the evidence about the fingerprints and the presence of potassium cyanide in her apron directly support her involvement, while the testimonies about her appearance might be minor details that don't necessarily contradict the main facts. Therefore, the more significant contradiction might be elsewhere.

Another point is Testimony 0 stating the man was reading the sports paper, while Evidence 3 shows a doodle by the victim saying 'MC Bomber' and a crossed-out '100,000.' This could indicate that the victim was involved in some illegal activity, possibly related to the 'MC Bomber' disc found later (Evidence 23). This might contradict the initial assumption that the victim was an ordinary programmer.

But focusing on the serving girl, the testimonies and evidence about her actions align more directly. The fingerprints and the presence of the poison in her pocket strongly support her role, making the testimonies about her appearance perhaps less relevant or possibly a distraction.

So, the main contradiction seems to be between the testimonies regarding her appearance and the evidence about her involvement in the poisoning. However, since the evidence directly links her to the crime, the testimonies about her appearance might not be as contradictory as they seem.
</think>

cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's see, the characters involved are from the Phoenix Wright series, and there's a murder at Trés Bien restaurant. The main suspect is Maggey Byrde, who was found guilty, but Phoenix is defending her. There are a bunch of evidences and testimonies to go through.

First, I need to look at the evidence list. Evidence 13 is the Coffee Cup, which contained potassium cyanide and had fingerprints from both the victim and Maggey. Evidence 14 is the Victim's Lottery Ticket, which was found in Maggey's possession. Evidence 12 is the Crime Photo, which shows the victim collapsing at a table, with a coffee cup nearby.

Now, looking at the testimonies, Testimony 1 says that the victim had a newspaper in his right hand and was rustling it. Testimony 3 mentions that the serving girl brought over the javaccino, and the victim took a sip with his free hand.

So, the Coffee Cup was in the victim's hand, but the Crime Photo shows it was knocked over. If the victim was holding the coffee cup, but it was also covered in Maggey's fingerprints, that might suggest that Maggey was involved in placing the poison. However, the testimonies say the victim was holding a newspaper, not the coffee cup. That seems contradictory because the evidence suggests the coffee cup was in his hand, but the testimony says he wasn't holding it.

Wait, but the Crime Photo shows the coffee cup was knocked over, not in the victim's hand. So maybe the victim wasn't holding it when he collapsed. That would align with the testimonies that he had a newspaper in his hand. So the contradiction isn't between the testimonies and the evidence, but maybe between the evidence and the testimonies regarding who was holding what.

Alternatively, maybe the key contradiction is that the Coffee Cup was in Maggey's fingerprints, implying she handled it, but the testimonies say she wasn't the one serving it. Or perhaps the victim was holding the newspaper, so the coffee cup was elsewhere, making the evidence and testimony consistent.

I think the main contradiction is between Evidence 13 (Coffee Cup) and Testimony 1 (newspaper in his right hand). If the Coffee Cup was in his hand, but the testimony says he was holding a newspaper, that's a conflict. But the Crime Photo shows the coffee cup was on the table, not in his hand. So the testimonies match the Crime Photo, and the Coffee Cup evidence is consistent with the testimonies because he wasn't holding it when he collapsed.

Wait, but the Coffee Cup had his and Maggey's fingerprints, which suggests it was handled by both. But the testimonies say he took a sip from it, implying he was holding it. There's a conflict here because the Crime Photo shows it was knocked over, not in his hand. So the testimonies might be wrong if the evidence shows he was holding it.

I'm getting a bit confused. Let me try to summarize:

- Evidence 13: Coffee Cup had his and Maggey's fingerprints, and he took a sip.
- Testimony 1: He had a newspaper in his right hand and was rustling it.
- Crime Photo: Coffee cup was knocked over, not in his hand.

So, the testimonies say he wasn't holding the coffee cup, but the evidence says he was. That's a contradiction. Therefore, the evidence (Coffee Cup) and the testimonies (Testimony 1) contradict each other because they provide conflicting information about who was holding what at the time of the incident.
</think>

cot:
Alright, let's dive into this problem. I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this scenario. There's a lot of information here, so I'll need to carefully analyze each piece to see where they might clash.

First, I'll look at the testimonies. Testimony 1 says that the young boy slumped over the table as soon as he took one sip of his javaccino. This suggests that the victim, Glen Elg, took a sip of coffee and immediately collapsed. On the other hand, Testimony 2 mentions that the vase was knocked over, and the tablecloth got soaked. This implies that the vase was broken, likely by the victim.

Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 13 is the Coffee Cup, which contained potassium cyanide. It also mentions that the coffee had a lip stain and a floral handle. This aligns with the testimony that the victim took a sip, indicating he drank from the cup. However, the testimony about the vase being knocked over and the tablecloth soaked doesn't directly contradict this evidence. In fact, both the evidence and testimony describe separate actions: the victim drinking from the cup and the vase breaking.

These seem to be about the vase breaking, not the victim's actions. So, the contradiction might be between the testimonies themselves rather than with the evidence.

But the user is asking for evidence that contradicts testimony. So, perhaps the issue is that Testimony 1 suggests the victim took a sip and collapsed, while Evidence 13 shows the cup had potassium cyanide, which would explain the collapse. So, both align, not contradict.

Wait, maybe I'm overcomplicating this. Let me see: Testimony 1 says the victim took a sip and collapsed. Evidence 13 shows the cup had poison, so the collapse makes sense. They don't contradict; they support each other.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 2 about the vase being broken and the tablecloth soaked is separate from the victim's actions. So, there's no direct contradiction between evidence and testimony here.

Hmm, perhaps I need to look elsewhere. Let me check other testimonies and evidence. Testimony 0 mentions the young man was reading the sports paper, and Testimony 1 about the sip. Evidence 3 is the Sports Paper with a doodle, which aligns with Testimony 0. So, they support each other, not contradict.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 1 and Testimony 2. Testimony 1 talks about the victim's collapse after a sip, while Testimony 2 is about the vase breaking. These are separate events, so they don't contradict each other but describe different aspects of the incident.

I'm a bit stuck here. Perhaps the key is to realize that the evidence supports the testimonies, so there's no direct contradiction. But the user wants a pair that contradicts, so maybe I need to look elsewhere.

Alternatively, perhaps the issue is that Testimony 1 says the victim took a sip and collapsed, but Evidence 13 shows the cup had potassium cyanide, which would cause immediate collapse. So, the evidence supports the testimony, not contradicting it.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is that Testimony 1 says the victim took a sip and collapsed, but Evidence 13 shows the cup had a lip stain and a floral handle, which suggests the victim took a sip, so they align. Therefore, no contradiction.

I think I need to look at the testimonies again. Testimony 1: victim took a sip and collapsed. Testimony 2: vase broke. Testimony 3: tablecloth soaked. Testimony 4: vase broken. So, these testimonies are about different actions. The evidence (coffee cup with poison) supports Testimony 1, but the other testimonies are about the vase breaking, which is supported by Evidence 12 (Crime Photo showing vase intact) or Evidence 18 (Victor's Testimony about breaking the vase). Wait, Evidence 12 is the Crime Photo, which shows an intact vase. So, if the Crime Photo shows an intact vase, but Testimony 2 says the vase was broken, that would be a contradiction.

So, Evidence 12: Crime Photo shows an intact vase. Testimony 2: Victor broke the vase. These contradict because the photo shows the vase was still intact, but the testimony claims it was broken.

Therefore, the evidence and testimony in question are Evidence 12 (Crime Photo) and Testimony 2 (Victor broke the vase). They contradict because the photo shows the vase was whole, while the testimony claims it was broken.

I think that's the correct pair. So, the answer should be Evidence 12 and Testimony 2.
